Study Title: Trastuzumab Deruxtecan in HER2-Mutant Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer.
Conclusion: Trastuzumab deruxtecan showed durable anticancer activity in patients with previously treated HER2-mutant NSCLC, but it also had toxic effects including interstitial lung disease that was fatal in two cases.
Primary Outcome: Objective response as assessed by independent central review
Results for the Primary Outcome: 55% of the patients (95% CI, 44 to 65)
Comparator: Patients with metastatic HER2-mutant NSCLC that was refractory to standard treatment

Study Title: Biologic and Clinical Efficacy of LentiGlobin for Sickle Cell Disease.
Conclusion: Treatment with LentiGlobin resulted in complete resolution of severe vaso-occlusive events.
Results for the Primary Outcome: 25 patients could be evaluated and all had resolution of severe vaso-occlusive events, as compared with a median of 3.5 events per year (range, 2.0 to 13.5) in the 24 months before enrollment.
Comparator: Group A, Group B, Group C

Study Title: Randomized Trial of Cytoreductive Surgery for Relapsed Ovarian Cancer.
Conclusion: Cytoreductive surgery followed by chemotherapy resulted in longer overall survival than chemotherapy alone.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median overall survival was 53.7 months in the surgery group and 46.0 months in the no-surgery group (hazard ratio for death, 0.75; 95% confidence interval, 0.59 to 0.96; P = 0.02).
Comparator: Cytoreductive surgery and chemotherapy vs. chemotherapy alone

Study Title: Effect of Long-term Supplementation With Marine Omega-3 Fatty Acids vs Placebo on Risk of Depression or Clinically Relevant Depressive Symptoms and on Change in Mood Scores: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Omega-3 supplements do not prevent depression in adults.
Primary Outcome: Risk of depression or clinically relevant depressive symptoms; mean difference in mood score (8-item Patient Health Questionnaire [PHQ-8] depression scale)
Results for the Primary Outcome: the mean difference in change in PHQ-8 score was 0.03 points (95% CI, -0.01 to 0.07; P = .19).

Study Title: Betibeglogene Autotemcel Gene Therapy for Non-b0/b0 Genotype b-Thalassemia.
Conclusion: Treatment with beti-cel resulted in a sustained HbA(T87Q) level and a total hemoglobin level that was high enough to enable transfusion independence in most patients with a non-b(0)/b(0) genotype, including those younger than 12 years of age.
Primary Outcome: Transfusion independence (i.e., a weighted average hemoglobin level of >=9 g per deciliter without red-cell transfusions for >=12 months)
Results for the Primary Outcome: Transfusion independence occurred in 20 of 22 patients who could be evaluated (91%), including 6 of 7 patients (86%) who were younger than 12 years of age.

Study Title: Evaluation of geriatric assessment and management on the toxic effects of cancer treatment (GAP70+): a cluster-randomised study.
Conclusion: A geriatric assessment intervention for older patients with advanced cancer reduced serious toxic effects from cancer treatment.
Primary Outcome: Proportion of patients who had any grade 3-5 toxic effect (based on National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events version 4) over 3 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: A lower proportion of patients in the intervention group had grade 3-5 toxic effects (177 [51%] of 349 patients) compared with the usual care group (263 [71%] of 369 patients; relative risk [RR] 0*74 (95% CI 0*64-0*86; p=0*0001).
Blinding: Masked oncology clinicians reviewed medical records to verify
Comparator: Intervention group and usual care group

Study Title: Effect of an Oncology Nurse-Led Primary Palliative Care Intervention on Patients With Advanced Cancer: The CONNECT Cluster Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: The CONNECT intervention, which was delivered by oncology nurses, did not improve patient-reported outcomes at 3 months.
Results for the Primary Outcome: At 3 months, no difference in mean (SD) quality-of-life score was found between the CONNECT and standard care groups (130.7 [28.2] vs 134.1 [28.1]; adjusted mean difference, 1.20; 95% CI, -2.75 to 5.15; P = .55).

Study Title: 21-Gene Assay to Inform Chemotherapy Benefit in Node-Positive Breast Cancer.
Conclusion: Error
Results for the Primary Outcome: Among postmenopausal women, invasive disease-free survival at 5 years was 91.9% in the endocrine-only group and 91.3% in the chemoendocrine group, with no chemotherapy benefit (hazard ratio for invasive disease recurrence, new primary cancer [breast cancer or another type], or death, 1.02; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.82 to 1.26; P = 0.89). Among premenopausal women, invasive disease-free survival at 5 years was 89.0% with endocrine-only therapy and 93.9% with chemoendocrine therapy (hazard ratio, 0.60; 95% CI, 0.43 to 0.83; P = 0.002), with a similar increase in distant relapse-free survival (hazard ratio, 0.58; 95% CI, 0.39 to 0.87; P = 0.009).
Comparator: Endocrine therapy only vs. chemotherapy plus endocrine therapy

Study Title: Lutetium-177-PSMA-617 for Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer.
Conclusion: Radioligand therapy with (177)Lu-PSMA-617 prolonged imaging-based progression-free survival when added to standard care in patients with advanced PSMA-positive metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median, 8.7 vs. 3.4 months; hazard ratio for progression or death, 0.40; 99.2% confidence interval [CI], 0.29 to 0.57; P<0.001
Comparator: (177)Lu-PSMA-617 plus standard care vs. standard care alone

Study Title: MRI-Targeted or Standard Biopsy in Prostate Cancer Screening.
Conclusion: MRI with targeted and standard biopsy in men with MRI results suggestive of prostate cancer was noninferior to standard biopsy for detecting clinically significant prostate cancer and resulted in less detection of clinically insignificant cancer.
Primary Outcome: Proportion of men in the intention-to-treat population in whom clinically significant cancer (Gleason score >=7) was diagnosed
Results for the Primary Outcome: Clinically significant cancer was diagnosed in 192 men (21%) in the experimental biopsy group, as compared with 106 men (18%) in the standard biopsy group (difference, 3 percentage points; 95% confidence interval [CI], -1 to 7; P<0.001 for noninferiority).
Comparator: Standard biopsy group and experimental biopsy group

Study Title: KTE-X19 for relapsed or refractory adult B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia: phase 2 results of the single-arm, open-label, multicentre ZUMA-3 study.
Conclusion: KTE-X19 showed a high rate of complete remission or complete remission with incomplete haematological recovery in adult patients with relapsed or refractory B-precursor acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, with the median overall survival not reached in responding patients, and a manageable safety profile.
Primary Outcome: Rate of overall complete remission or complete remission with incomplete haematological recovery by central assessment
Results for the Primary Outcome: 39 patients (71%; 95% CI 57-82, p<0*0001) had complete remission or complete remission with incomplete haematological recovery, with 31 (56%) patients reaching complete remission

Study Title: Duration of Adjuvant Aromatase-Inhibitor Therapy in Postmenopausal Breast Cancer.
Study Abbreviation: Austrian Breast and Colorectal Cancer Study Group
Conclusion: Extending hormone therapy by 5 years provided no benefit over a 2-year extension but was associated with a greater risk of bone fracture.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Disease progression or death occurred in 335 women in each treatment group in the primary-analysis set at 8 years (hazard ratio, 0.99; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.85 to 1.15; P = 0.90).

Study Title: Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for first-line treatment of advanced oesophageal cancer (KEYNOTE-590): a randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 3 study.
Conclusion: Error
Results for the Primary Outcome: Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy was superior to placebo plus chemotherapy for overall survival in patients with oesophageal squamous cell carcinoma and PD-L1 CPS of 10 or more (median 13*9 months vs 8*8 months; hazard ratio 0*57 [95% CI 0*43-0*75]; p<0*0001), oesophageal squamous cell carcinoma (12*6 months vs 9*8 months; 0*72 [0*60-0*88]; p=0*0006), PD-L1 CPS of 10 or more (13*5 months vs 9*4 months; 0*62 [0*49-0*78]; p<0*0001), and in all randomised patients (12*4 months vs 9*8 months; 0*73 [0*62-0*86]; p<0*0001). Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy was superior to placebo plus
Comparator: Pembrolizumab plus chemotherapy vs placebo plus chemotherapy

Study Title: Adjuvant Pembrolizumab after Nephrectomy in Renal-Cell Carcinoma.
Conclusion: Treatment with pembrolizumab led to a significant improvement in disease-free survival compared to placebo in patients with kidney cancer who were at high risk for recurrence after surgery.
Primary Outcome: Disease-free survival according to the investigator's assessment
Results for the Primary Outcome: Pembrolizumab therapy was associated with significantly longer disease-free survival than placebo (disease-free survival at 24 months, 77.3% vs. 68.1%; hazard ratio for recurrence or death, 0.68; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.53 to 0.87; P = 0.002 [two-sided]).
Comparator: Patients with clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma who were at high risk for recurrence after nephrectomy, with or without metastasectomy, randomly assigned to receive either adjuvant pembrolizumab or placebo intravenously once every 3 weeks

Study Title: Adjuvant atezolizumab after adjuvant chemotherapy in resected stage IB-IIIA non-small-cell lung cancer (IMpower010): a randomised, multicentre, open-label, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: Atezolizumab after adjuvant chemotherapy offers a promising treatment option for patients with resected early-stage NSCLC, with improved disease-free survival compared to best supportive care.
Results for the Primary Outcome: In the stage II-IIIA population whose tumours expressed PD-L1 on 1% or more of tumour cells, atezolizumab treatment improved disease-free survival compared with best supportive care (HR 0*66; 95% CI 0*50-0*88; p=0*0039). In the ITT population, HR for disease-free survival was 0*81 (0*67-0*99; p=0*040).

Study Title: Sotorasib for Lung Cancers with KRAS p.G12C Mutation.
Conclusion: Sotorasib therapy led to a durable clinical benefit without new safety signals in patients with previously treated KRAS p.G12C-mutated NSCLC.
Primary Outcome: Objective response (complete or partial response) according to independent central review
Results for the Primary Outcome: An objective response was observed in 46 patients (37.1%; 95% CI, 28.6 to 46.2), including in 4 (3.2%) who had a complete response and in 42 (33.9%) who had a partial response.

Study Title: 18F-fluciclovine-PET/CT imaging versus conventional imaging alone to guide postprostatectomy salvage radiotherapy for prostate cancer (EMPIRE-1): a single centre, open-label, phase 2/3 randomised controlled trial.
Conclusion: The use of (18)F-fluciclovine-PET/CT in postprostatectomy radiotherapy decision making and planning significantly improved survival free
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median survival was not reached (95% CI 35*2-not reached; 33% of 81 patients had events) in the conventional imaging group compared with not reached (95% CI not reached-not reached; 20% of 76 patients) in the (18)F-fluciclovine-PET/CT group, and 3 year event-free survival was 63*0% (95% CI 49*2-74*0) in the conventional imaging group versus 75*5% (95% CI 62*5-84*6) for (18)F-fluciclovine-PET/CT (difference 12*5; 95% CI 4*3-20*8; p=0*0028).

Study Title: Adjuvant Olaparib for Patients with BRCA1- or BRCA2-Mutated Breast Cancer.
Study Abbreviation: OlympiA Clinical Trial Steering Committee and Investigators
Authors: Tutt, Andrew N J et al.
Conclusion: Olaparib was associated with significantly longer survival free of invasive or distant disease than was placebo.
Results for the Primary Outcome: 3-year invasive disease-free survival was 85.9% in the olaparib group and 77.1% in the placebo group (difference, 8.8 percentage points; 95% confidence interval [CI], 4.5 to 13.0; hazard ratio for invasive disease or death, 0.58; 99.5% CI, 0.41 to 0.82; P<0.001).

Study Title: First-line nivolumab plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone for advanced gastric, gastro-oesophageal junction, and oesophageal adenocarcinoma (CheckMate 649): a randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: Nivolumab plus chemotherapy is a new standard first-line treatment for advanced gastric, gastro-oesophageal junction, or oesophageal adenocarcinoma, as it has superior overall survival and progression-free survival, along with an acceptable safety profile.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Nivolumab plus chemotherapy resulted in significant improvements in OS (hazard ratio [HR] 0*71 [98*4% CI 0*59-0*86]; p<0*0001) and PFS (HR 0*68 [98 % CI 0*56-0*81]; p<0*0001) versus chemotherapy alone in patients with a PD-L1 CPS of five or more.
Comparator: Nivolumab plus chemotherapy versus chemotherapy alone

Study Title: Ciltacabtagene autoleucel, a B-cell maturation antigen-directed chimeric antigen receptor T-cell therapy in patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (CARTITUDE-1): a phase 1b/2 open-label study.
Conclusion: A single cilta-cel infusion at the target dose of 0*75 x 10(6) CAR-positive viable T cells per kg led to early, deep, and durable responses in heavily pretreated patients with multiple myeloma with a manageable safety profile.
Primary Outcome: Safety and confirmation of the recommended phase 2 dose (phase 1b), and overall response rate (phase 2) in all patients who received treatment
Results for the Primary Outcome: Overall response rate was 97% (95% CI 91*2-99*4; 94 of 97 patients); 65 (67%) achieved stringent complete response; time to first response was 1 month (IQR 0*9-1*0).

Study Title: Ipatasertib plus abiraterone and prednisolone in metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (IPATential150): a multicentre, randomised, double-blind, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: Error
Results for the Primary Outcome: In the PTEN-loss-by-immunohistochemistry population, median radiographical progression-free survival was 16*5 months (95% CI 13*9-17*0) in the placebo-abiraterone group and 18*5 months (16*3-22*1) in the ipatasertib-abiraterone group (hazard ratio [HR] 0*77 [95% CI 0*61-0*98]; p=0*034; significant at a=0*04). In the intention-to-treat population, median progression-free survival was 16*6 months (95% CI 15*6-19*1) in the placebo-abiraterone group and 19*2 months (16*5-22*3) in the ipatasertib-abiraterone group (HR 0*84 [95% CI 0*71-0
Comparator: Ipatasertib plus abiraterone vs. placebo plus abiraterone

Study Title: Metronomic capecitabine as adjuvant therapy in locoregionally advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma: a multicentre, open-label, parallel-group, randomised, controlled, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: The addition of metronomic adjuvant capecitabine to chemoradiotherapy significantly improved failure-free survival in patients with high-risk locoregionally advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma, with a manageable safety profile.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Failure-free survival at 3 years was significantly higher in the metronomic capecitabine group (85*3% [95% CI 80*4-90*6]) than in the standard therapy group (75*7% [69*9-81*9]), with a stratified hazard ratio of 0*50 (95% CI 0*32-0*79; p=0*0023).
Comparator: Metronomic capecitabine group (n=204) and Standard therapy group (n=202)

Study Title: Vemurafenib plus Rituximab in Refractory or Relapsed Hairy-Cell Leukemia.
Conclusion: A short, chemotherapy-free, nonmyelotoxic regimen of vemurafenib plus rituximab was associated with a durable complete response in most patients with refractory or relapsed HCL.
Primary Outcome: Complete response at the end of planned treatment
Results for the Primary Outcome: Complete response was observed in 26 patients (87%) in the intention-to-treat population.
Comparator: Patients with refractory or relapsed HCL

Study Title: Effect of Marine Omega-3 Fatty Acid and Vitamin D Supplementation on Incident Atrial Fibrillation: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Treatment with EPA-DHA or vitamin D3, compared with placebo, resulted in no significant difference in the risk of incident AF over a median follow-up of more than 5 years. The findings do not support the use of either agent for the primary prevention of incident AF.
Primary Outcome: Incident AF confirmed by medical record review
Results for the Primary Outcome: Incident AF events occurred in 469 (3.7%) vs 431 (3.4%) participants, respectively (hazard ratio, 1.09; 95% CI, 0.96-1.25; P = .19).
Comparator: EPA-DHA and vitamin D3 vs. placebo

Study Title: Effect of Celecoxib vs Placebo Added to Standard Adjuvant Therapy on Disease-Free Survival Among Patients With Stage III Colon Cancer: The CALGB/SWOG 80702 (Alliance) Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: The addition of celecoxib to adjuvant chemotherapy with fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) did not significantly improve disease-free survival in patients with stage III colon cancer.
Results for the Primary Outcome: 3-year disease-free survival was 76.3% for celecoxib-treated patients vs 73.4% for placebo-treated patients (hazard ratio [HR] for disease recurrence or death, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.76-1.03; P = .12).

Study Title: Sacituzumab Govitecan in Metastatic Triple-Negative Breast Cancer.
Conclusion: Sacituzumab govitecan was more effective than single-agent chemotherapy in prolonging progression-free and overall survival in patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median progression-free survival was 5.6 months with sacituzumab govitecan and 1.7 months with chemotherapy (hazard ratio for disease progression or death, 0.41; 95% CI, 0.32 to 0.52; P<0.001).

Study Title: Adjuvant Nivolumab in Resected Esophageal or Gastroesophageal Junction Cancer.
Conclusion: Patients with resected esophageal or gastroesophageal junction cancer who received nivolumab adjuvant therapy had a significantly longer disease-free survival than those who received placebo.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median disease-free survival was 22.4 months (95% CI, 16.6 to 34.0) for the nivolumab group and 11.0 months (95% CI, 8.3 to 14.3) for the placebo group (hazard ratio for disease recurrence or death, 0.69; 96.4% CI, 0.56 to 0.86; P<0.001).

Study Title: Pirtobrutinib in relapsed or refractory B-cell malignancies (BRUIN): a phase 1/2 study.
Conclusion: Pirtobrutinib was safe and effective in treating multiple B-cell malignancies, including those previously treated with covalent BTK inhibitors, and might address an unmet need for alternative therapies for these patients.
Primary Outcome: Maximum tolerated dose (phase 1) and overall response rate (ORR; phase 2)
Results for the Primary Outcome: ORR with pirtobrutinib was 62% (95% CI 53-71) in 121 efficacy evaluable patients with chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) or small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) treated with a previous covalent BTK inhibitor (median previous lines of treatment 4). ORR was 52% (95% CI 38-66) in 52 efficacy evaluable patients with mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) previously treated with covalent BTK inhibitors.
Comparator: Patients with previously treated B-cell malignancies

Study Title: [177Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 versus cabazitaxel in patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (TheraP): a randomised, open-label, phase 2 trial.
Study Abbreviation: TheraP Trial Investigators and the Australian and New Zealand Urogenital and
Conclusion: [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 compared with cabazitaxel in men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer led to a higher PSA response and fewer grade 3 or 4 adverse events.
Primary Outcome: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) response defined by a reduction of at least 50% from baseline
Results for the Primary Outcome: PSA responses were more frequent among men in the [(177)Lu]Lu-PSMA-617 group than in the cabazitaxel group (65 vs 37 PSA responses; 66% vs 37% by intention to treat; difference 29% (95% CI 16-42; p<0*0001; and 66% vs 44% by treatment received; difference 23% [9-37]; p=0*0016).

Study Title: Transdermal oestradiol for androgen suppression in prostate cancer: long-term cardiovascular outcomes from the randomised Prostate Adenocarcinoma Transcutaneous Hormone (PATCH) trial programme.
Conclusion: Long-term data comparing tE2 patches with LHRHa show no evidence of a difference between treatments in cardiovascular mortality or morbidity. Oestrogens administered transdermally should be reconsidered for androgen suppression in the management of prostate cancer.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Hazard ratio 1*11, 95% CI 0*80-1*53; p=0*54 (including sudden deaths without post-mortem report); 1*20, 0*86-1*68; p=0*29 (confirmed group only).

Study Title: A comparison of sunitinib with cabozantinib, crizotinib, and savolitinib for treatment of advanced papillary renal cell carcinoma: a randomised, open-label, phase 2 trial.
Conclusion: Cabozantinib treatment resulted in significantly longer progression-free survival compared with sunitinib in patients with metastatic PRCC.
Results for the Primary Outcome: PFS was longer in patients in the cabozantinib group (median 9*0 months, 95% CI 6-12) than in the sunitinib group (5*6 months, 3-7; hazard ratio for progression or death 0*60, 0*37-0*97, one-sided p=0*019).

Study Title: Adavosertib plus gemcitabine for platinum-resistant or platinum-refractory recurrent ovarian cancer: a double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, phase 2 trial.
Conclusion: Combining a Wee1 inhibitor with gemcitabine appears to be an effective treatment for high-grade serous ovarian cancer.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Progression-free survival was longer with adavosertib plus gemcitabine (median 4*6 months [95% CI 3*6-6*4] with adavosertib plus gemcitabine vs 3*0 months [1*8-3*8] with placebo plus gemcitabine; hazard ratio 0*55 [95% CI 0*35-0*90]; log-rank p=0*015).
Comparator: Adavosertib plus gemcitabine vs placebo plus gemcitabine

Study Title: Effect of Capecitabine Maintenance Therapy Using Lower Dosage and Higher Frequency vs Observation on Disease-Free Survival Among Patients With Early-Stage Triple-Negative Breast Cancer Who Had Received Standard Treatment: The SYSUCC-001 Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Low-dose capecitabine maintenance therapy for 1 year, compared with observation, resulted in significantly improved 5-year disease-free survival for women with early-stage triple-negative breast cancer who received standard adjuvant treatment.
Results for the Primary Outcome: 5-year disease-free survival was 82.8% in the capecitabine group and 73.0% in the observation group (hazard ratio [HR] for risk of recurrence or death, 0.64 [95% CI, 0.42-0.95]; P = .03).

Study Title: First-line nivolumab plus ipilimumab in unresectable malignant pleural mesothelioma (CheckMate 743): a multicentre, randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab significantly extended overall survival compared to chemotherapy, with 2-year overall survival rates of 41% in the nivolumab plus ipilimumab group and 27% in the chemotherapy group.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median overall survival 18.1 months (95% CI 16.8-21.4) in nivolumab plus ipilimumab group vs. 14.1 months (12.4-16.2) in chemotherapy group; hazard ratio 0.74 (96.6% CI 0.60-0.91); p=0.0020; 2-year overall survival rates were 41% (95% CI 35.1-46.5) in nivolumab plus ipilimumab group and 27% (21.9-32.4) in chemotherapy group.
Comparator: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab vs. platinum plus pemetrexed chemotherapy

Study Title: Cemiplimab monotherapy for first-line treatment of advanced non-small-cell lung cancer with PD-L1 of at least 50%: a multicentre, open-label, global, phase 3, randomised, controlled trial.
Conclusion: Cemiplimab monotherapy significantly improved overall survival and progression-free survival compared with chemotherapy in patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer with PD-L1 of at least 50%, providing a potential new treatment option for this patient population.
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median overall survival was not reached (95% CI 17*9-not evaluable) with cemiplimab (n=283) versus 14*2 months (11*2-17*5) with chemotherapy (n=280; hazard ratio [HR] 0*57 [0*42-0*77]; p=0*0002). Median progression-free survival was 8*2 months (6*1-8*8) with cemiplimab versus 5*7 months (4*5-6*2) with chemotherapy (HR 0*54 [0*43-0*68]; p<0*0001).
